revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox military person |name=Eric Harrison |image=A03916HarrisonPetre1914CroppedHarrison.jpg |image_size=172 |alt=Half-portrait of man in cap and goggles seated in the open cockpit of a biplane |caption=Eric Harrison at Central Flying School, 1914 |birth_date={{birth date|df=yes|1886|8|10}} |death_date={{death date and age|1945|9|5|1886|8|10|df=yes}} |birth_place=[[Castlemaine, Victoria|Castlemaine]], Victoria |death_place=[[Melbourne]] |nickname= |allegiance=Australia |branch= {{plainlist| *[[Australian Military Forces]] *[[Royal Australian Air Force]] }} |serviceyears=1912–45 |rank=[[Group Captain]] |unit= |commands= {{plainlist| *[[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School]] (1917–18) *Directorate of Aeronautical Inspection (1928–45) }} |battles= {{plainlist| *World War I *World War II }} |awards= |laterwork= }}
'''Eric Harrison''' (10 August 1886 – 5 September 1945) was an Australian aviator who made the country's first military flight, and helped lay the groundwork for the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF). Born in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], he was a [[flight instructor|flying instructor]] in Britain when, in 1912, he answered the Australian [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Defence Department]]'s call for pilots to form an aviation school. Along with [[Henry Petre]], he established Australia's first air base at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|Point Cook]], Victoria, and its inaugural training unit, the [[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School]] (CFS), before making his historic flight in March 1914. Following the [[Military history of Australia during World War I|outbreak of World War I]], when Petre went on active service with the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]], Harrison took charge of instructing student pilots of the [[Australian Flying Corps]] at CFS.
Harrison transferred to the RAAF as one of its founding members in 1921, and spent much of the inter-war period in technical services and air accident investigation. Promoted to [[group captain]] in 1935, he retired from the Air Force three years later when his post of Director of Aeronautical Inspection was transferred to the public service. He continued to serve in the same capacity as a civilian until his sudden death from heart disease at the age of fifty-nine, just after the end of World War II. Harrison's technical abilities and association with military flying from its earliest days in Australia earned him the title of "Father of the RAAF" for many years, until the mantle was assumed by Air Marshal [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Sir Richard Williams]].
==Early career== Born on 10 August 1886 at Clinkers Hill near [[Castlemaine, Victoria|Castlemaine]], Victoria, Harrison was the son of [[Printer (publisher)|printer]] and [[Stationery|stationer]] Joseph Harrison, and his English-born wife Ann.<ref name="ADB">McCarthy, "Harrison, Eric (1886–1945)"</ref> He attended Castlemaine Grammar School before starting work as a motor mechanic. Keen to fly from the first time he saw an aeroplane, he travelled to Britain in March 1911 and trained as a pilot at the [[Bristol Aeroplane Company|Bristol School]] on [[Salisbury Plain]]. Six months later, having accumulated some thirty minutes' flight time, he qualified for his [[Royal Aero Club]] Aviator's Certificate, becoming only the third Australian to do so.<ref name="Stephens & Isaacs">Stephens; Isaacs, ''High Fliers'', pp.14–15</ref><ref name="Molkentin">Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp.5–6</ref> Gaining employment as an instructor for Bristol, he taught flying on behalf of the company in Spain and Italy, as well as in [[Halberstadt]], Germany, where he became aware first-hand of that country's militarism; some of the students he trained and examined later served as pilots in the ''[[Luftstreitkräfte]]'' during World War I.<ref name="ADB"/><ref name="Odgers">Odgers, ''Air Force Australia'', pp.13–14</ref>
[[File:A03915PetreHarrison1914.jpg|thumb|left|260px|Lieutenants Petre (left) and Harrison (right) in a B.E.2 at Central Flying School, Point Cook, 1914|alt=Two men in flying gear seated in tandem open cockpits of a biplane with a four-bladed propeller]] In December 1911, the Australian [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Defence Department]] advertised in the United Kingdom for "two competent mechanists and aviators" to establish a flying corps and training school. [[Henry Petre]], a former [[solicitor]] employed by [[Handley Page]], and H.R. Busteed, then Bristol's chief test pilot, successfully applied.<ref name="Gillison pp.710-711">Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/33.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force 1939–1942'', pp.710–711]</ref><ref name="Stephens pp.2-4">Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp.2–4</ref> Petre was commissioned as a [[lieutenant]] in the [[Australian Military Forces]] on 6 August 1912, but Busteed withdrew his application in October and Harrison took his place, gaining his commission on 16 December.<ref name="ADB"/><ref name="Gillison pp.710-711"/> While his new salary of [[Australian pound|£]]400 was little improvement on what he was earning in Britain, Harrison was happy to have an excuse to return home.<ref name="Molkentin"/>
Petre selected [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|Point Cook]], Victoria, to become the site for the Army's proposed [[Central Flying School RAAF|Central Flying School]] (CFS) in March 1913; meanwhile Harrison remained in Britain temporarily, ordering the facility's complement of aircraft including two [[Société Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés|Deperdussin]] monoplanes, two [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2]] biplanes, and a [[Bristol Boxkite]] for initial training.<ref name="Wilson">Wilson, ''The Brotherhood of Airmen'', pp.1–3</ref><ref>Eather, ''Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force'', p.8</ref> By January 1914, the pair had established the school with themselves as instructors, augmented by four mechanics and three other staff. Harrison made Australia's first military flight in the Boxkite on Sunday, 1 March 1914, followed by a second in the same aircraft with Petre as passenger, then a third by himself in a Deperdussin.<ref name="Odgers"/><ref name="Stephens pp.2-4"/> On 29 June, Harrison married Kathleen Prendergast, daughter of future [[Premier of Victoria]] [[George Prendergast]], at St Mary's Catholic Church in [[West Melbourne, Victoria|West Melbourne]].<ref name="ADB"/><ref>[http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A110290b.htm Prendergast, George Michael] at [http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/adbonline.htm Australian Dictionary of Biography Online]. Retrieved on 30 October 2009.</ref>
==World War I== [[File:VIC1693Harrison1916.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Lieutenant Harrison (left) in a Bristol Boxkite, greeted by Lieutenant Colonel Edgar Hercules Reynolds, first commanding officer of No. 1 Squadron AFC, at Point Cook, c. 1916|alt=Pilot seated in open-framed biplane, shaking hands with a man in military uniform who wears a peaked cap]] Its coterie of personnel by now being referred to as the [[Australian Flying Corps]] (AFC), CFS commenced its first course on 17 August 1914, two weeks after the [[Military history of Australia during World War I|outbreak of World War I]]. Its students included Captain [[Thomas White (Australian politician)|Thomas White]] and Lieutenant [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]], with Harrison providing initial training to solo standard and Petre advanced instruction.<ref name="Stephens pp.2-4"/><ref name="Cutlack pp.1-3">Cutlack, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/9/chapters/01.pdf ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp.1–3]</ref> In September, Harrison was given command of a flying unit that accompanied the [[Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force]] to [[Rabaul]] in [[German New Guinea]]. With little in the way of enemy resistance, however, the aircraft were never assembled in country and he had to return without leading the first Australian airmen into combat, a distinction that instead went to Petre as commander of the [[Mesopotamian Half Flight]] the following year.<ref name="Stephens & Isaacs"/><ref name="Wilson"/>
With Petre on active duty, Harrison took on the main responsibility for providing basic flying training to the pilots of the first three squadrons to be formed in Australia for overseas service. Many of his students would go on to play a prominent role in the future [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF), including [[William Anderson (RAAF officer)|Bill Anderson]], [[Harry Cobby]], [[Adrian Cole (RAAF officer)|Adrian Cole]], [[Frank McNamara (VC)|Frank McNamara]], [[Lawrence Wackett]], and [[Henry Wrigley]].<ref name="Stephens p.5">Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp.5–9</ref> Having graduated twenty-four new pilots by the end of 1915, Harrison was able to establish the first AFC squadron, designated No. 67 (Australian) Squadron, [[Royal Flying Corps]]; it was however commonly known as [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron AFC]] from its inception, and officially so from 1 January 1918.<ref>Molkentin, ''Fire in the Sky'', pp.23–24</ref> The unit departed for Egypt in March 1916 under the command of [[Lieutenant Colonel]] E.H. Reynolds.<ref name="Stephens p.5"/> [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 3]] and [[No. 4 Squadron RAAF|4 Squadrons AFC]] were formed at Point Cook in late 1916 to operate in France following advanced training in England.<ref>Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp.9,16</ref> In addition to his instructional and administrative duties, Harrison put his mechanical abilities to use initiating the building of aero engines in Australia and maintaining the CFS's complement of airframes; according to Wackett, only Harrison had the skill to keep the obsolescent machines in the air. He was appointed officer-in-charge of CFS in June 1917 with the temporary rank of [[major]]; this was made permanent in September 1918.<ref name="ADB"/><ref name="Stephens & Isaacs"/> The CFS was disbanded at Point Cook on 31 December 1919.<ref>[http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_14870.asp Central flying schools] at [[Australian War Memorial]]. Retrieved on 30 October 2009.</ref>
==Interbellum and World War II== Harrison began a long association with engineering and air safety when he was posted to Britain for secondment to the Aeronautical Inspection Directorate following the end of World War I.<ref name="Stephens & Isaacs"/> He transferred as a [[flight lieutenant]] (honorary [[squadron leader]]) to the newly formed Australian Air Force in March 1921, becoming one of its twenty-one founding officers; the prefix "Royal" was added to the service's name in August that year.<ref>Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p.34</ref><ref>Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp.29–31</ref> Dissatisfied with his RAAF rank considering his leading position in the pre-war Central Flying School, Harrison appealed for greater seniority. As a result, he was appointed [[Air Liaison Officer]] to the [[Air Ministry]] in London, with promotion to the substantive rank of squadron leader.<ref>Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp.37–38</ref> Returning to Australia in 1925, he was appointed Assistant Director of Technical Services in 1927, and soon after helped form the RAAF's Air Accident Investigation Committee. The following year he became Director of Aeronautical Inspection, receiving promotion to [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]] on 1 July 1928. Harrison's position took him throughout the country, inspecting equipment and investigating the causes of air crashes. Promoted [[group captain]] on 1 January 1935,<ref name="ADB"/><ref name="Stephens & Isaacs"/> he took charge of the Federal government's resources committee for aircraft, aero engines, and motor transport, one of a number of subcommittees on the Defence Resources Board set up to investigate and report on the readiness of Australian industry to provide munitions for defence in the event of international conflict.<ref>Mellor, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/34/chapters/02.pdf ''The Role of Science and Industry'', p.28]</ref>
[[File:DC2Kyeema.jpg|thumb|left|280px|The DC-2 airliner ''Kyeema''; Harrison was a member of the court of inquiry into its crash on 25 October 1938|alt=Half portrait of stewardess in dark cap and uniform in front of nose and engines of piston-engined airliner, emblazoned with the name ''Kyeema'']] In 1937, Harrison returned to Britain for further study of accident investigation methods, as well as aircraft production. His position as Director of Aeronautical Inspection was civilianised on 12 March 1938, which saw him retired from the RAAF but continuing in his role.<ref name="ADB"/><ref name="Third Brother">Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp.312–314</ref> He was a member of the court of inquiry into the [[1938 Kyeema Crash|crash on 25 October]] of the [[Douglas DC-2]] airliner ''Kyeema'', which overshot [[Essendon, Victoria|Essendon]] airport in low cloud, killing all fourteen passengers and four crew members. The inquiry's report singled out Major Melville Langslow, Finance Member on both the Civil Aviation Board and the RAAF Air Board, for criticism over cost-cutting measures that had held up trials of safety beacons designed for such eventualities. According to Air Force historian Chris Coulthard-Clark, when Langslow was appointed Secretary at the [[Department of Air (Australia)|Department of Air]] in November the following year, he went out of his way to "make life difficult" for Harrison, causing "bitterness and friction within the department", and necessitating the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Vice Marshal [[Stanley Goble]], to take steps to shield the safety inspector from the new Secretary's ire.<ref name="Third Brother"/>
Harrison held the position of Director of Aeronautical Inspection throughout World War II, his staff numbering more than 1,200 by 1945.<ref name="ADB"/> A reorganisation of the directorate in 1940 had permitted qualified civilian engineers to be recruited for work that required increasing technical expertise, without them having to join the Air Force.<ref>Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/05.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force 1939–1942'', p.95]</ref> In July the same year, Harrison proposed the construction of a series of test houses to help decentralise chemical, mechanical and metrological testing of materials used in the manufacture of munitions that previously had to go through either the Munitions Supply Laboratories or the National Standards Laboratory. The result was a major improvement in the speed of testing and, according to the [[Australia in the War of 1939–1945|official history of Australia in the war]], "a fuller use of the country's scientific and technical manpower".<ref>Mellor, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/34/chapters/07.pdf ''The Role of Science and Industry'', p.155]</ref> Harrison's daughter Greta joined the [[Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force]], and by the end of the war was ranked [[Flight Lieutenant|flight officer]].<ref name="Argus">{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article975287 |title=Father of RAAF dies |newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=7 September 1945 |accessdate=22 April 2012 |page=2 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:A04588WilliamsPetreHarrison1914.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Instructors and students of the first CFS course at Point Cook in 1914: [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]] and [[Thomas White (Australian politician)|Thomas White]] (back row); George Merz, [[Henry Petre]], Eric Harrison, and David Manwell (front row)|alt=Six men in military uniforms with peaked caps, two standing and four seated, in front of a biplane]] On 5 September 1945, just as the war had ended, Harrison died suddenly of [[Cerebrovascular disease|hypertensive cerebrovascular disease]] at his home in the Melbourne suburb of [[Brighton, Victoria|Brighton]]; he was survived by his wife and daughter, and cremated.<ref name="ADB"/><ref name="Stephens & Isaacs"/> The [[Minister for Air (Australia)|Minister for Air]], [[Arthur Drakeford]], commented that "all members of the service, and, indeed, all Australians interested in aviation, must feel his loss as the snapping of one of the last links with the pioneer days of flying".<ref name="Argus"/> One of the original Deperdussins that Harrison ordered and helped assemble for the Central Flying School in 1914 later went on display at the [[Australian War Memorial]] in [[Canberra]].<ref name="ADB"/>
Despite his accomplishments in overseeing the training of every student pilot who served in the Australian Flying Corps during World War I, Eric Harrison received no decorations or other official recognition, prompting Group Captain Mark Lax, at the 1999 RAAF History Conference, to describe him as "perhaps the unluckiest of the entire AFC ... an unsung hero".<ref>Sutherland, ''Command and Leadership'', pp.37–38</ref> He was, however, generally considered to be the "Father of the RAAF" until the title eventually settled on Air Marshal Sir Richard Williams. Harrison's early technical expertise, long association with Australian military aviation as a founder member of the AFC and the RAAF, and "more assertive" personality tended to overshadow the contributions of Henry Petre, whom historian Douglas Gillison considered "equally entitled" to such an accolade. Reviewing the contributions of Petre and Harrison in his volume of The Australian Centenary History of Defence in 2001, Alan Stephens concluded that "perhaps any judgement would not only be moot but also gratuitous, as by circumstance and achievement both men properly belong in the pantheon of the RAAF".<ref name="Gillison pp.710-711"/><ref name="Stephens pp.2-4"/>
